. Because the standard reduction potential of cobalt (II) (
Hydrogen Electrode (NHE)) is lower than the potential for evolution of hydrogen (0 V vs. NHE), a
low pH will promote the evolution of H
. To avoid this side reaction, the cathode material should
also exhibit a high overpotential over hydrogen. Prabaharan et al. and Lupi et al. used stainless steel
and aluminum, respectively, as cathode material [
], which provide a relatively high hydrogen
overpotential, are made of low-cost material, and allow easy recovery of metallic Co deposit.

, except by Recupyl, who precipitated Li
], and Rockwood Lithium, who produced LiOH

The ﬁrst reaction is thermodynamically favored when comparing the standard potential of O
1.36 V). However, the slower kinetics of oxygen evolution can promote oxidation
of chloride anions to chlorine. On the other hand, cobalt is frequently used as an oxygen reduction
catalyst in fuel cells. Therefore, considering the proximity of electromotive forces (EMF) for both
ect of local concentration gradient, both reactions are most probably
happening. Previous literature does not provide a clear answer to this.
